title: Why are lithium sodium and potassium grouped together? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because these alkali have identical VALENCE electronic configurations… [math]Li[/math], [math]Z=3[/math], [math]1s^{2}2s^{1}[/math]; [math]Na[/math], [math]Z=11[/math], [math]1s^{2}2s^{2}2p^{6};3s^{1}[/math]; [math]K[/math], [math]Z=19[/math], [math]1s^{2}2s^{2}2p^{6}3s^{2}3p^{6}4s^{1}[/math]; And each metal has a SINGLE valence electron, and thus the alkali metals ARE SUPERBLY REDUCING…. Potassium, for which the valence electron is FARTHER removed from the nuclear core, is FAR MORE reactive than sodium, and lithium…
